awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jonathan J. Zhu is "Stability phenomena for geometric variational problems". The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Fernando Marques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Work supported by this grant focused on the theory of prescribed mean curvature surfaces, including mean curvature flow. The mean curvature of a surface models the action of surface tension, when surface energy is proportional to surface area. Consequently, mean curvature flow models the motion of soap films, while prescribed mean curvature surfaces model certain equilibrium or steady states. Minimal surfaces are the special case of zero mean curvature, or equilibrium under no external forces. The study of surfaces with prescribed mean curvature has a rich history, which has motivated the development of theory in other mathematical fields, such as partial differential equations and topology, and which has been applied to other fields, such as physics and chemistry. A significant amount of research has been devoted to studying singularities (points where a surface fails to be smooth) of surfaces of prescribed mean curvature. 

 

The results produced under this grant include the following highlights:

 

 - The PI investigated the least possible area of minimal surfaces under various conditions. With K. Naff, we proved a sharp lower bound for the area of a minimal surface in a negatively curved ball, in terms of its minimum distance to the center of the ball. Our methods also cover the zero curvature case (conjectured by Alexander, Hoffman and Osserman, and recently proven by Brendle and Hung) and partially cover the positive curvature case. 

 

 - With K. Sackel, A. Song, and U. Varolgunes, the PI investigated certain quantifications of the symplectic non-squeezing theorem. The non-squeezing theorem states that a ball does not fit into a cylinder of smaller radius, while preserving the so-called symplectic structure; we determined how much must be removed from the ball until it fits. Our work combined techniques from symplectic geometry and minimal surface theory, and establishes a new research direction. 

 

 - The PI continued to develop theories for the min-max construction of curves and surfaces with prescribed curvature. With X. Zhou, we constructed networks of curves with prescribed constant geodesic curvature. With C. Li and X. Zhou, we constructed so-called capillary surfaces, which have prescribed constant mean curvature and contact angle with a container. These surfaces model, for instance, the steady state of soap films in a tub under various environmental forces. 

 

 - With N. Edelen, M. Ivaki, and R. Haslhofer, the PI investigated the dynamics of soap films with a free-boundary condition.  We proved results on the size and nature of singularities that arise in certain free-boundary mean curvature flows. These results address, for instance, the nature of soap bubbles moving freely in a tub.

 

 - The PI developed a perturbative method for proving so-called Łojasiewicz inequalities, which constrain the long-time behavior of gradient flows. We applied this method to mean curvature flow near certain cylindrical singularity models. This gave a new proof of Colding and Minicozzi’s inequalities for round cylinders, and resolved a conjecture of theirs for so-called Abresch-Langer cylinders. With A. Sun, we used the same method to study mean curvature flow near products of spheres. 

 

In addition to the research described above, while support by this grant the PI also supervised one undergraduate thesis, co-organized the Differential Geometry and Geometric Analysis seminar at Princeton University, co-organized an international conference, and refereed 18 articles for 11 journals. 

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2022
Modified by: Jonathan J Zhu

Work supported by this grant focused on the theory of prescribed mean curvature surfaces, including mean curvature flow. The mean curvature of a surface models the action of surface tension, when surface energy is proportional to surface area. Consequently, mean curvature flow models the motion of soap films, while prescribed mean curvature surfaces model certain equilibrium or steady states. Minimal surfaces are the special case of zero mean curvature, or equilibrium under no external forces. The study of surfaces with prescribed mean curvature has a rich history, which has motivated the development of theory in other mathematical fields, such as partial differential equations and topology, and which has been applied to other fields, such as physics and chemistry. A significant amount of research has been devoted to studying singularities (points where a surface fails to be smooth) of surfaces of prescribed mean curvature. 

 

The results produced under this grant include the following highlights:

 

 - The PI investigated the least possible area of minimal surfaces under various conditions. With K. Naff, we proved a sharp lower bound for the area of a minimal surface in a negatively curved ball, in terms of its minimum distance to the center of the ball. Our methods also cover the zero curvature case (conjectured by Alexander, Hoffman and Osserman, and recently proven by Brendle and Hung) and partially cover the positive curvature case.

Zhou, we constructed so-called capillary surfaces, which have prescribed constant mean curvature and contact angle with a container. We proved results on the size and nature of singularities that arise in certain free-boundary mean curvature flows. These results address, for instance, the nature of soap bubbles moving freely in a tub.

 

 - The PI developed a perturbative method for proving so-called Łojasiewicz inequalities, which constrain the long-time behavior of gradient flows. This gave a new proof of Colding and Minicozzi’s inequalities for round cylinders, and resolved a conjecture of theirs for so-called Abresch-Langer cylinders. With A. Sun, we used the same method to study mean curvature flow near products of spheres. 

 

In addition to the research described above, while support by this grant the PI also supervised one undergraduate thesis, co-organized the Differential Geometry and Geometric Analysis seminar at Princeton University, co-organized an international conference, and refereed 18 articles for 11 journals.
